sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying motor
message_1: A motor has a coil of 200 turns and a radius of 0.05 meters. The coil carries a current of 2 amperes. What is the magnetic field at a point 0.02 meters away from the center of the coil?
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at a point 0.02 meters away from the center of the coil, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a circular loop:

B = (μ₀ * I * N * r²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where:
B is the magnetic field
μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A)
I is the current (2 A)
N is the number of turns (200)
r is the radius of the coil (0.05 m)
R is the distance from the center of the coil (0.02 m)
x is the axial distance from the center of the coil (0 in this case, since we are considering a point on the plane of the coil)

Plugging in the values:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * 200 * (0.05 m)²) / (2 * (0.02 m² + 0²)^(3/2))

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * 200 * 0.0025 m²) / (2 * (0.0004 m²)^(3/2))

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * 200 * 0.0025 m²) / (2 * 0.0008 m³)

B = (1.6π × 10^(-6) Tm²) / 0.0008 m³

B ≈ 6.283 × 10^(-6) T

So, the magnetic field at a point 0.02 meters away from the center of the coil is approximately 6.283 × 10^(-6) Tesla.
